acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on the fact that the substance is classified as Category A4 (as metal mercury and inorganic mercury compounds) by ACGIH (2001) and Group 3 (as metal mercury and inorganic mercury compounds) by IARC (1993).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
No data available
As for the mutagenicity/genotoxicity of inorganic mercury, refer to "ID285, Mercury Chloride (II), CAS: 7487-94-7."

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: No data available, though being inorganic compounds containing oxygen. The substance is "Non-combustible" but may intensify fire, according to ICSC (2001). Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1641) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
Based on the evidence of malformation in offspring at non-maternally toxic doses, described in EHC 118 (1991).
As for the reproductive toxicity of inorganic mercury, refer to "ID285, Mercury Chloride (II), CAS: 7487-94-7."

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): "reddening, irritation of the eye/skin/respiratory tract." The substance is thus considered to possess an eye irritation potential of unknown degree. Although classified as Category 2A-2B, it should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): "reddening, irritation of the eye/skin/respiratory tract." The substance is thus considered to possess a skin irritation potential of unknown degree and could be placed in Category 2 or 3. It is classified as Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale:
Mercury is classified into "Skin Sensitizing Substance" by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy, and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1"* by the Japan Society for Occupational Health. These classifications, though not specifying mercury oxide, seem to include mercury compounds. Mercury oxide, which is a mercury compound, should thus cause skin sensitization. 
* There is a provision to the effect that "the category refers to the substance concerned and its compounds, but does not identify all substances causing respiratory/skin sensitization.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the description in ICSC (J): "The substance may adversely affect the kidney and cause kidney damage" (ICSC (J) (2001)).

Note: According to CICAD 50 (2003), "renal failure, cardiovascular collapse and severe digestive organ damage are considered to be the causes of death following oral exposure to inorganic mercury. Most common findings among these are gastrointestinal tract lesion and renal failure. Exposure to inorganic mercury appears to induce nephrotic syndrome in humans."

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (nervous system)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence including "hemiparesis, generalized muscle rigidity, muscle tremor, sign of acrodynia, coma" following dermal exposure (though the study was limited to infants) (CICAD 50 (2003)), and "irritation of the eye, skin and respiratory tract" (ICSC (J) (2001)).

Note: According to CICAD 50 (2003), "renal failure, cardiovascular collapse and severe digestive organ damage are considered to be the causes of death following oral exposure to inorganic mercury. Most common findings among these are gastrointestinal tract lesion and renal failure. Exposure to inorganic mercury appears to induce nephrotic syndrome in humans."
